basics.name: Ryan Copley
basics.label: Senior Software Developer
basics.summary: Cincinnati raised, process driven software developer with a Bachelor's Degree in Computer Science from Bowling Green State University. Proven iOS developer with a large showcase of iOS applications. Extensive knowledge of the iOS SDK, as well as many backend languages. Web developer & code reviewer of USA Today, a Django based website. Lover of ECMAScript 6, a great UX, and fun projects. I read ARM assembly for fun.

work.summary: Lead, architected, and developed a scalable native mobile editorial application framework that powers 50+ iOS Apps. Designed to scale from the beginning, A new app can be created and deployed with tools provided to project managers, without the need of a developer. We utilized heavy dependency injection to prevent code bloat, well defined configurations to vary the user experience, and heavy usage of continuous integration to orchestrate repetitive workflows. Trusted project maintainer & code reviewer for the USA Today Network platform, which delivers over 100 million daily page views across across 100+ sites. Various backend APIs were developed with go or NodeJS, with mandatory unit tests and black box tests.

Developed BGSU branded iOS apps for various departments under the supervision of Dr. Joseph Chao. Worked with a small team of 4 mobile developers (2 iOS, 2 Android). Built 3 applications from the ground up to App Store over the course of just over a year.

Developed & Designed iOS Music App for the Ampache backend. Currently a paid app in the app store, and has sold over 1,000 units. I am a known contributor to the underlying open source project Ampache. Commercial Music-As-A-Service branch was under development but never launched.
Developed & maintained enterprise finance software that consumed receipts and bills from various vendors to track resource allocation, project cost, and unused services.

Developed a file hosting website for a community that ended up growing out of control, tens of thousands of registered and verifed user accounts, terabytes of files uploaded, and an average sustained network usage of 400 mbps.
